title: China still buying Canadian canola through a UAE backdoor
text:
Canadian canola shipments to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) shot up 533 per cent in September amid a diplomatic dispute that’s halted most shipments from Canada to China. Canadian canola seed is now being crushed in the UAE and the oil exported to China, according to Neil Townsend, senior analyst at FarmLink in Winnipeg. (Bloomberg)

Talking point: China used to buy 40 per cent of Canada’s canola seed, and its move to halt shipments in March—citing contamination by pests, which Canadian officials dispute—has left growers struggling to move their crops. Importers and analysts argue the ban is retaliation for the 2018 arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou in Vancouver. Canada has challenged China’s ban at the World Trade Organization, but that body takes an average of more than two years to settle disputes.
